text: I pressed a hand on Lucia’s shoulder and whispered, “Don’t move. I’ll distract them—you use the chance to save her.”
Lucia’s eyes widened, her voice trembling. “Are you crazy? That’s a ritual circle!”
I didn’t answer. I drew a deep breath and slowly stepped out of the shadows. Blue light flowed along the floor, and the air was thick with damp chill.
I stepped into the glowing circle, facing the robed leader directly.
“Forgive the intrusion,” I said, raising both hands and keeping my tone as calm as I could. “I mean no harm—I just want to know… why is she here?”
The leader lifted his head, his mask reflecting the circle’s light. “Outsider, you should not be here. This place belongs to the Echo.”
🎲 [Charisma Check: Success] Your tone is steady enough to make him hesitate for a moment.
“‘The Echo’? She’s the town’s healer. Did you capture her to heal someone—or to sacrifice her?”
“She understands the art of the Cycle,” he said softly. “We merely help her remember. Mortals know nothing of the price of the soul.”
“Maybe not,” I replied, lifting the brass die in my hand. “But balance—should belong to the one who rolls it.”
The leader’s breath faltered slightly. The chanting in the circle wavered.
Lucia seized the moment, moving to the edge of the formation. Light flowed from her fingertips along the chains.
I saw her spell begin to take effect—and quickly drew the leader’s attention again.
“This ‘Cycle’ you speak of… does it mean rebirth?” I asked.
“Yes.” His voice deepened. “She abandoned her power—so I will use it properly.”
“And you?” I stepped closer. “Does that power truly belong to you?”
His expression froze. The glow of the circle began to distort.
Lucia broke the final seal, and the blue light surged backward. The formation’s energy turned on itself.
“Mentor!” Lucia cried, catching Alicia as she fell.
A burst of energy flooded the chamber, drowning everything in blue light.
The leader roared, “You destroyed the Cycle!”
The backlash tore through his sigils. He was consumed by the blue fire and reduced to ash.
Dust drifted through the air—only Lucia’s ragged breathing remained.
“The mentor’s alive… her breathing’s weak, but she’s still here.” Her voice trembled.
“Come on, this place is about to collapse.”
We left the underground chamber one after another. Cold wind rushed in through the broken opening, and snowflakes landed on Alicia’s hair.
I held Alicia in my arms as she murmured faintly in her sleep, “...Thank you…”
The wind swept down the street, scattering the last of the ashes. Silent snow continued to fall.
